content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, I would choose a strategy that maximizes my overall earnings over the 75 rounds. Given the payoff structure, it seems that both choices (R and B) have their advantages and disadvantages depending on my opponent's choice.

However, if we assume rationality in our opponent, they will likely try to exploit any pattern or predictability in our choices. If I consistently choose R, for example, after a few rounds, they could figure out that I am more likely to pick R and start choosing B whenever it is their turn. This would result in me earning 0$ every time they make this prediction, which is not ideal.

On the other hand, if I consistently choose B, they might start choosing R, as that gives them a higher payoff. In this case, I'd earn 35$ for each of these rounds, but since it is less than what we both get when we both pick R (45$), it would still not be the optimal strategy in the long run.

One potential strategy to mitigate this problem could be to implement a mixed strategy where I randomly select R and B with approximately equal probability. This way, my opponent won't be able to predict my choice easily, and we might both end up with a higher average payoff than if I stick to one choice consistently.

Ultimately, it is impossible for me to know the exact strategy my opponent will employ, but given the information provided, a mixed strategy seems like a reasonable approach to maximize my overall earnings in this game.

With that said, my choice would be R{R}, as I intend to randomly switch between R and B throughout the 75 rounds. However, it's important to note that the exact probability distribution for switching between R and B will depend on factors such as how well my opponent can predict my choices and how much they value consistency in their own strategy.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 35$. Please play the next round.

Given that my opponent chose B in the previous round, I would now choose R, hoping to receive a payoff of 45$ if my opponent decides to stick with B again or 35$ if they change their strategy and choose R instead. However, since I cannot predict what my opponent will do, I must continue adapting my choices based on the information available in each round.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 35$. Please play the next round.

After receiving a payoff of 0$ in the previous round, I will switch my strategy and choose B for the next round to try and avoid continuing this pattern of earning 0$ whenever I pick R and my opponent picks B. By doing so, I have a chance of receiving a payoff of 45$ if my opponent chooses R again or 40$ if they stick with their current strategy of picking B. Again, it's important to note that my decision is based on the available information and the assumption that my opponent will continue employing some level of rationality in their choices.

With that said, my choice for the next round would be B{B}. I intend to continue adapting my strategy depending on the outcomes of each round and my opponent's apparent pattern (if any). However, it is crucial to remember that our opponents may not always be predictable or rational, so we must be prepared to adjust our strategies accordingly.
